questions.template: A {object} travels {distance} m in {time} s. What is its average speed?
questions.trap_explanation: Remember: speed = distance √∑ time, not the other way around!

questions.template: An object accelerates from {v0} m/s to {v1} m/s in {time} s. What is the acceleration?
questions.trap_explanation: Acceleration is CHANGE in velocity divided by time: a = (v - v‚ÇÄ) / t

questions.template: A ball is thrown straight up with initial velocity {v0} m/s. What is its velocity at the highest point? (Ignore air resistance)
questions.trap_explanation: At the highest point, the ball momentarily stops before falling back down. Velocity = 0!

questions.template: A car accelerates uniformly from rest at {a} m/s¬≤ for {time} s. How far does it travel?
questions.trap_explanation: Use s = ¬Ωat¬≤ when starting from rest. Don't forget the ¬Ω!

questions.template: A projectile is launched at {angle}¬∞ above horizontal with speed {v0} m/s. What is the horizontal component of velocity at the highest point?
questions.trap_explanation: Only vertical velocity is zero at the peak! Horizontal velocity stays constant (no air resistance).

questions.template: A {mass} kg object experiences a net force of {force} N. What is its acceleration?
questions.trap_explanation: Newton's Second Law: F = ma, so a = F/m

questions.template: A {mass} kg box is pushed across a floor with {applied} N of force. If friction is {friction} N, what is the net force?
questions.trap_explanation: Net force = applied force - friction (they oppose each other)

questions.template: You push against a wall with {force} N. According to Newton's Third Law, the wall pushes back with:
questions.trap_explanation: Action-reaction pairs are ALWAYS equal and opposite, regardless of motion!

questions.template: A {mass} kg object hangs from a rope in an elevator accelerating upward at {a} m/s¬≤. What is the tension in the rope? (g = 10 m/s¬≤)
questions.trap_explanation: When accelerating up, T = m(g + a). The tension must overcome gravity AND provide extra force for acceleration!

questions.template: Two blocks ({m1} kg and {m2} kg) are connected by a string and pulled across a frictionless surface by {force} N applied to the {m1} kg block. What is the tension in the string between them?
questions.trap_explanation: The string only pulls the back block. Tension = (m‚ÇÇ / total mass) √ó Applied Force

questions.template: A force of {force} N moves an object {distance} m in the direction of the force. How much work is done?
questions.trap_explanation: Work = Force √ó Distance (when force and motion are in the same direction)

questions.template: What is the kinetic energy of a {mass} kg object moving at {velocity} m/s?
questions.trap_explanation: KE = ¬Ωmv¬≤. Don't forget to SQUARE the velocity!

questions.template: A {mass} kg object is lifted {height} m. If it's then dropped, what is its speed just before hitting the ground? (g = 10 m/s¬≤)
questions.trap_explanation: Using energy conservation: mgh = ¬Ωmv¬≤, so v = ‚àö(2gh). Mass cancels out!

questions.template: A {power} W motor lifts a {mass} kg load at constant speed. How high can it lift the load in {time} s? (g = 10 m/s¬≤)
questions.trap_explanation: Power = Work/time = mgh/t, so h = Pt/(mg)

questions.template: A {mass} kg ball moving at {v1} m/s collides with a wall and bounces back at {v2} m/s. What is the change in kinetic energy?
questions.trap_explanation: ŒîKE = KE_final - KE_initial. If v‚ÇÇ < v‚ÇÅ, energy was lost!
